channel.title: Java?
channel.description: Ok, I am a total noob at java and I didnt know anywhere else to post this, so I thought i'd post it here. I make alot of SCAR scripts and I always been thinking about java. Now, what is java? What is or can it be used for? Is it hard? How can I start? What should I start doing IF I start? I dont know, im just asking stupid little questions... I want to learn something new, so why not java. If you want, post informative stuff for me concerning java. Sorry if this post is in the wrong section. ~jR

item.title: Java?
item.dc:creator: @ilyaostr9 io9
item.description:
@ilyaostr9 wrote:

Well, after you are done with Sun’s Java tutorial, use moparisthebest’s eBook (it actually works!)

http://www.moparisthebest.com/java

item.description:
@White_Castle wrote:

eBooks are so irritating, I barely get anything out of them. I guess you could go to the library and rent a book, but I don’t usually read a technical book in one sitting or even over the course of a month, so you might end up with some nasty fines (as did I :P).

item.title: Java?
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

junior:

Thanks for the link. So your saying java can be used to make 2D games and such? Sound interesting, im going to give this a shot sooner or later.

You can make 2d or 3d games with many languages…its simply a matter of picking a language and running with it. Java is nice because you have much flexibility and power without having to deal with issues present in C[++] such as memory management, garbage collection, etc. It’s also easier to learn than C imho, but apparently languages such as python are also much easier to learn than java. So really, it’s up to you what you’d like to learn

Read full topic

item.title: Java?
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

Java is a cross-platform object-oriented programming language. Like other general-purpose programming languages, it can be used for writing any kind of program you want to write, though it does some things better than it does others (3D graphics tend to be awkward or slow).

As compiled object-oriented languages go, it’s less complicated than C++, which is the major alternative. I haven’t had much experience with any other kind of language, so I really don’t know how it compares to, say, Ruby or Python.

A good place to start is always Sun’s Java Tutorial. In a while, someone will post here and tell you that you need to buy a book. This is probably true, eventually. But if you’re just starting out and aren’t sure if you want to stay with it, use an online tutorial.

Read full topic
